facts.text: Jagdish Prasad Ramnarayan Khandelwal admitted to Dr. Adatia's nursing home on 3 May 1964, diagnosed with acute appendicitis.
Patient's condition worsened after 24 hours; Dr. Shantilal J. Mehta diagnosed acute appendicitis with generalised peritonitis and advised immediate operation.
Dr. Adatia performed operation; appendix was gangrenous; patient developed paralysis of the ileum.
Patient removed to Bombay Hospital under Dr. Motwani on 10 May 1964; died on 13 May 1964.
Hospital issued Death Intimation Card as paralytic ileus and peritonitis following operation for acute appendicitis.
Appellant (Coroner of Bombay) allowed disposal of body without post-mortem, despite police request for inquest as post-operation death.
Coroner's Court registered inquest on 13 May 1964; inquest dates fixed in June, July, September, October 1964; appellant on leave in June-July causing delay.
On 3 October 1964, appellant ordered Mr. Adatia be called; earlier told Dr. Adatia that hospital cause of death would presume negligence.
Appellant told Dr. Motwani on 3 October 1964 that Dr. Adatia at fault but could be cleared; demanded Rs. 20,000.
Dr. Motwani conveyed proposal to Dr. Adatia, who refused; appellant reduced demand to Rs. 10,000, refused again.
On 4 October 1964, appellant contacted Dr. Jadhav (Superintendent Bombay Hospital) re cause of death; Dr. Motwani told Dr. Jadhav cause incorrect.
Dr. Jadhav said he would send amended deposition to Coroner.
On 5 October 1964, Drs. Motwani and Adatia decided to complain to Anti-Corruption Bureau; received harassing calls to contact appellant.
Appellant asked Dr. Motwani by 10 a.m. 7 October if Dr. Adatia willing to pay Rs. 10,000.
Dr. Motwani complained to Mugwe (Anti-Corruption); arranged tape recording at Dr. Motwani's residence on 7 October 1964.
On 7 October 1964, Mugwe, Sawant at Dr. Motwani's; recorded FIR; attached tape to phone; Dr. Motwani called appellant, conversations recorded.
Appointment fixed at 12 noon; Drs. Motwani and Adatia met appellant; demand raised to Rs. 15,000 (Rs. 5,000 to Coroner's Surgeon).
Dr. Adatia agreed to pay Rs. 15,000 on 9 October; paid to Dr. Motwani, who informed appellant by phone; to bring on 10 October.
On 10 October 1964, Dr. Motwani went to appellant's house at 10 a.m.; appellant not home; told wife he came to pay money; she said pay her; he left without paying.
Later on 10 October, at Dr. Adatia's, recorded call to appellant; arranged payment to wife on 12 October with loan letter.
On 11 October 1964, appellant called Dr. Motwani to come meet person for payment; declined.
On 12 October 1964, appellant cancelled appointment as Dr. Motwani didn't come on 11th; Mugwe ordered open investigation.
Appellant charged under sections 161, 385, 420 r/w 511 IPC.
Appellant denied demanding money or threatening Dr. Adatia.
Trial Court and High Court convicted appellant under 161 and 385 IPC; sentence: 6 months SI u/s 161, 3 months SI u/s 385, fine Rs. 10,000 or 6 months further SI.
Appellant suffered heart attacks; paid fine Rs. 10,000.

legal_issues.text: Whether tape-recorded telephonic conversations between Dr. Motwani and appellant are admissible, allegedly in contravention of section 25 Indian Telegraph Act.
Whether tape-recorded conversations are inadmissible under section 162 CrPC as obtained during investigation.
Whether appellant attempted to obtain gratification under sections 161 and 385 IPC.
Whether sentence of imprisonment should be interfered with given fine paid and appellant's heart attacks.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tape-recorded evidence inadmissible as illegally obtained in contravention of section 25 Indian Telegraph Act; attaching recorder to phone is offence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 25 Indian Telegraph Act; Rule 149 Telegraph Rules; Articles 20(3) and 21 Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Tape-recorded conversations occurred during investigation as per Mugwe's instructions, hence inadmissible under section 162 CrPC.
No attempt to obtain gratification; conversations show mere bargain, not attempt.
Sentence of six months imprisonment should be modified as fine of Rs. 10,000 paid and appellant suffered heart attacks.

court_reasoning.text: Tape-recording attached with Dr. Motwani's consent; no interception or tampering under s.25 Telegraph Act; voluntary, not coercive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Police did not damage or tamper; recorded what Dr. Motwani allowed, akin to overhearing.

court_reasoning.text: Tape-recordings admissible as relevant under Evidence Act ss.7,8 (res gestae); voice identified, no tampering; precedents accept such evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tape is primary evidence; admissible even if obtained irregularly if genuine.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of Art.20(3) or 21; voluntary conversation, no compulsion to incriminate; privacy not invaded unlawfully.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Protection for innocent, not guilty public servants.

court_reasoning.text: Not during investigation under s.162 CrPC; conversation between private parties, not statements to police.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.162 applies to oral examinations by police.

court_reasoning.text: Facts show demand started 3 Oct 1964 (Rs.20,000 reduced to 10,000, raised to 15,000), repeated calls, meetings prove attempt to obtain gratification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Corroborated by tapes and doctors' evidence.

court_reasoning.text: No interference with sentence; gravity of offence by public servant, no sentence undergone, health/ fine payment insufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Position held and offence nature outweigh.

holdings.text: Tape-recorded conversations admissible notwithstanding alleged Telegraph Act violation.
Tape-recordings not hit by s.162 CrPC.
Appellant guilty of attempting to obtain gratification u/ss.161,385 IPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri N. Sri Rama Reddy etc. v. Shri V. V. Giri
precedents_cited.relevance: Tape-recorded conversation admissible to contradict witness.

precedents_cited.case_name: Yusufalli Esmail Nagree v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Tape-recorded conversation admissible even if unnoticed.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Pratap Singh v. State of Punjab
Magraj Patodia v. R. K. Birla Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Documents procured illegally admissible if relevant and genuine.
Evidence admissible regardless of how obtained, if not confession.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under 161 and 385 for bribery and criminal intimidation attempt.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Telegraph Act, 1885
statutes_cited.relevance: No violation in consensual tape-recording; not interception.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Tape conversations not statements during investigation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Tape admissible as relevant fact, res gestae, to test veracity.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No self-incrimination or deprivation without procedure; voluntary.

outcome.summary: Appeal against conviction and sentence under sections 161 and 385 IPC confirmed; tape evidence held admissible; no merit in contentions on attempt or sentence.

key_quotes.text: "Tape recorded conversation is admissible provided first the conversation is relevant to the matters in issue secondly, there is identification of the voice and thirdly, the accuracy of the tape recorded conversation is proved by eliminating the possibility of erasing the tape record."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It matters not how you get it; if you steal it even, it would be admissible in evidence."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting R. v. Leatham on admissibility of illegally obtained evidence.

key_quotes.text: "The protection is not for the guilty citizen against the efforts of the police to vindicate the law and prevent corruption of public servants."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits on Art.21 privacy in corruption cases.
